segment.source: Configure Windows Defender ATP endpoints
segment.target: Configure Windows Defender ATP endpoints

segment.source: Use Group Policy or SCCM to deploy the configuration package or do manual registry changes on endpoints so that they are onboarded to the service.
segment.target: Use Group Policy or SCCM to deploy the configuration package or do manual registry changes on endpoints so that they are onboarded to the service.

segment.source: Configure Windows Defender ATP endpoints
segment.target: Configure Windows Defender ATP endpoints

segment.source: Applies to:
segment.target: Applies to:

segment.source: Windows 10 Insider Preview Build 14332 or later
segment.target: Windows 10 Insider Preview Build 14332 or later

segment.source: Windows Defender Advanced Threat Protection (Windows Defender ATP)
segment.target: Windows Defender Advanced Threat Protection (Windows Defender ATP)

segment.source: [Some information relates to pre-released product which may be substantially modified before it's commercially released.
segment.target: [Some information relates to pre-released product which may be substantially modified before it's commercially released.

segment.source: Microsoft makes no warranties, express or implied, with respect to the information provided here.]
segment.target: Microsoft makes no warranties, express or implied, with respect to the information provided here.]

segment.source: You can use a Group Policy (GP) configuration package, a System Center Configuration Manager (SCCM) package, or an automated script to configure endpoints.
segment.target: You can use a Group Policy (GP) configuration package, a System Center Configuration Manager (SCCM) package, or an automated script to configure endpoints.

segment.source: Configure with Group Policy
segment.target: Configure with Group Policy

segment.source: Using the GP configuration package ensures your endpoints will be correctly configured to report to the Windows Defender ATP service.
segment.target: Using the GP configuration package ensures your endpoints will be correctly configured to report to the Windows Defender ATP service.

segment.source: Note To use GP updates to deploy the package, you must be on Windows Server 2008 R2 or later.
segment.target: Note To use GP updates to deploy the package, you must be on Windows Server 2008 R2 or later.

segment.source: The endpoints must be running Windows 10 Insider Preview Build 14332 or later.
segment.target: The endpoints must be running Windows 10 Insider Preview Build 14332 or later.

segment.source: Open the GP configuration package .zip file (WindowsDefenderATPOnboardingPackage.zip) that you downloaded from the service onboarding wizard.
segment.target: Open the GP configuration package .zip file (WindowsDefenderATPOnboardingPackage.zip) that you downloaded from the service onboarding wizard.

segment.source: You can also get the package from the Windows Defender ATP portal:
segment.target: You can also get the package from the Windows Defender ATP portal:

segment.source: a.
segment.target: a.

segment.source: Click Client onboarding on the Navigation pane.
segment.target: Click Client onboarding on the Navigation pane.

segment.source: b.
segment.target: b.

segment.source: Select Group Policy, click Download package and save the .zip file.
segment.target: Select Group Policy, click Download package and save the .zip file.

segment.source: Extract the contents of the .zip file to a shared, read-only location that can be accessed by the endpoints.
segment.target: Extract the contents of the .zip file to a shared, read-only location that can be accessed by the endpoints.

segment.source: You should have a folder called OptionalParamsPolicy and the file WindowsDefenderATPOnboardingScript.cmd.
segment.target: You should have a folder called OptionalParamsPolicy and the file WindowsDefenderATPOnboardingScript.cmd.

segment.source: Open the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC), right-click the Group Policy Object (GPO) you want to configure and click Edit.
segment.target: Open the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC), right-click the Group Policy Object (GPO) you want to configure and click Edit.

segment.source: In the Group Policy Management Editor, go to Computer configuration, then Preferences, and then Control panel settings.
segment.target: In the Group Policy Management Editor, go to Computer configuration, then Preferences, and then Control panel settings.

segment.source: Right-click Scheduled tasks, point to New, and then click Immediate task.
segment.target: Right-click Scheduled tasks, point to New, and then click Immediate task.

segment.source: In the Task window that opens, go to the General tab.
segment.target: In the Task window that opens, go to the General tab.

segment.source: Choose the local SYSTEM user account under Security options.
segment.target: Choose the local SYSTEM user account under Security options.

segment.source: Select Run whether user is logged on or not and check the Run with highest privileges check box.
segment.target: Select Run whether user is logged on or not and check the Run with highest privileges check box.

segment.source: Go to the Actions tab and click New... Ensure that Start a program is selected in the Action field.
segment.target: Go to the Actions tab and click New... Ensure that Start a program is selected in the Action field.

segment.source: Enter the file name and location of the shared WindowsDefenderATPOnboardingScript.cmd file.
segment.target: Enter the file name and location of the shared WindowsDefenderATPOnboardingScript.cmd file.

segment.source: Click OK and close any open GPMC windows.
segment.target: Click OK and close any open GPMC windows.

segment.source: For additional settings, see the Additional configuration settings section.
segment.target: For additional settings, see the Additional configuration settings section.

segment.source: Configure with System Center Configuration Manager
segment.target: Configure with System Center Configuration Manager

segment.source: Open the SCCM configuration package .zip file (WindowsDefenderATPOnboardingPackage.zip) that you downloaded from the service onboarding wizard.
segment.target: Open the SCCM configuration package .zip file (WindowsDefenderATPOnboardingPackage.zip) that you downloaded from the service onboarding wizard.

segment.source: You can also get the package from the Windows Defender ATP portal:
segment.target: You can also get the package from the Windows Defender ATP portal:

segment.source: a.
segment.target: a.

segment.source: Click Client onboarding on the Navigation pane.
segment.target: Click Client onboarding on the Navigation pane.

segment.source: b.
segment.target: b.

segment.source: Select System Center Configuration Manager, click Download package, and save the .zip file.
segment.target: Select System Center Configuration Manager, click Download package, and save the .zip file.

segment.source: Extract the contents of the .zip file to a shared, read-only location that can be accessed by the network administrators who will deploy the package.
segment.target: Extract the contents of the .zip file to a shared, read-only location that can be accessed by the network administrators who will deploy the package.

segment.source: You should have a file called WindowsDefenderATPOnboardingScript.cmd.
segment.target: You should have a file called WindowsDefenderATPOnboardingScript.cmd.

segment.source: Import the configuration package by following the steps in the How to Create Packages and Programs in Configuration Manager topic.
segment.target: Import the configuration package by following the steps in the How to Create Packages and Programs in Configuration Manager topic.

segment.source: Deploy the package by following the steps in the How to Deploy Packages and Programs in Configuration Manager topic.
segment.target: Deploy the package by following the steps in the How to Deploy Packages and Programs in Configuration Manager topic.

segment.source: a.
segment.target: a.

segment.source: Choose a predefined device collection to deploy the package to.
segment.target: Choose a predefined device collection to deploy the package to.

segment.source: Configure endpoints individually with an automated script
segment.target: Configure endpoints individually with an automated script

segment.source: You can also manually onboard individual endpoints to Windows Defender ATP.
segment.target: You can also manually onboard individual endpoints to Windows Defender ATP.

segment.source: You might want to do this first when testing the service before you commit to onboarding all endpoints in your network.
segment.target: You might want to do this first when testing the service before you commit to onboarding all endpoints in your network.

segment.source: Open the GP configuration package .zip file (WindowsDefenderATPOnboardingPackage.zip) that you downloaded from the service onboarding wizard.
segment.target: Open the GP configuration package .zip file (WindowsDefenderATPOnboardingPackage.zip) that you downloaded from the service onboarding wizard.

segment.source: You can also get the package from the Windows Defender ATP portal:
segment.target: You can also get the package from the Windows Defender ATP portal:

segment.source: a.
segment.target: a.

segment.source: Click Client onboarding on the Navigation pane.
segment.target: Click Client onboarding on the Navigation pane.

segment.source: b.
segment.target: b.

segment.source: Select Local Script, click Download package and save the .zip file.
segment.target: Select Local Script, click Download package and save the .zip file.

segment.source: Extract the contents of the configuration package to a location on the endpoint you want to onboard (for example, the Desktop).
segment.target: Extract the contents of the configuration package to a location on the endpoint you want to onboard (for example, the Desktop).

segment.source: You should have a file called WindowsDefenderATPOnboardingScript.cmd.
segment.target: You should have a file called WindowsDefenderATPOnboardingScript.cmd.

segment.source: Open an elevated command-line prompt on the endpoint and run the script:
segment.target: Open an elevated command-line prompt on the endpoint and run the script:

segment.source: a.
segment.target: a.

segment.source: Click Start and type cmd.
segment.target: Click Start and type cmd.

segment.source: b.
segment.target: b.

segment.source: Right-click Command prompt and select Run as administrator.
segment.target: Right-click Command prompt and select Run as administrator.

segment.source: Window Start menu pointing to Run as administrator
segment.target: Window Start menu pointing to Run as administrator

segment.source: Type the location of the script file.
segment.target: Type the location of the script file.

segment.source: If you copied the file to the desktop, type:
segment.target: If you copied the file to the desktop, type:

segment.source: Press the Enter key or click OK.
segment.target: Press the Enter key or click OK.

segment.source: See the Troubleshoot Windows Defender Advanced Threat Protection onboarding issues topic for details on how you can manually validate that the endpoint is compliant and correctly reports telemetry.
segment.target: See the Troubleshoot Windows Defender Advanced Threat Protection onboarding issues topic for details on how you can manually validate that the endpoint is compliant and correctly reports telemetry.

segment.target: Related topics

segment.target: Configure endpoint proxy and Internet connectivity settings
